title: Crypto’s Killer App? Why Everyone’s Really Into Stablecoins Right Now

network effects, meaning they get more
valuable the more nodes on the network.
And we're in a situation here with
stable coins where 99% of the nodes that
matter are highly regulated. I mean,
it's kind of remarkable that we have
trillions of dollars in monthly volume
where 99% of the participants the
network feel like they can't join the
network right now. So, the big unlock is

The benefit is just so obvious that I

dominant. Welcome to Web 3 with A16Z.
I'm Robert Hackett. Today, we're taking
a deep look at why stable coins have
emerged as one of the most promising
applications in crypto today and how
they could reshape everything from
international remittances to point of
sale payments. I'm joined by Chris
Dixon, founder and managing partner of

Times bestselling book Read Right Own,
and Sam Broner, a deal partner at A6Z
Crypto, who focuses on stable coins.
Together, we unpack the technical and
regulatory foundations of stable coins.
We explore the cracks in the current
payment system and we look ahead to what
becomes possible once digital dollars go
mainstream. We also dig into why the
future of money might end up looking a
lot more like email or the web than a
bank. As a reminder, none of the content
should be taken as tax, business, legal,
or investment advice. Please see
az.com/disclosures for more important
information, including a link to a list
of our investments.
The internet has done a terrific job in
some respects removing intermediaries.
You could look at the way that the web
has challenged legacy media, how the
internet and connectivity has kind of
supercharged open- source code, getting
around proprietary software. What has

that you need a global system of

You're always going to be giving your

then of course they got extracted.
That's what an extractive network is.
That's sort of a large part of the

and sort of default on integration with

We're seeing people who want to save

correspondent bank things, you send
a,000 bucks, you might be paying 100. I

Just to just to add to that and this
goes to for those interested this is
what my book read right on is about like
basically the idea that in summary the
interesting thing we do with the
internet is we build networks on top.
You know Twitter, email, the web, like
the most powerful digital services are
networks. The network is a digital
service that gets more valuable the more
people use it. They're important because
they help solve information distribution
and coordination problems. And the basic
thesis of the book is that there's three
known ways to build networks. There's
the sort of the original way that the
internet built networks, which I call
protocol networks, sometimes just called
protocols. That's email and the web.
There's standards. They're almost like a
language. Everyone sort of gets together
and says we'll speak English. We'll
speak HTTP. And then they all built
software and services that connect to
that conic lingua franca. And what's
great about that is you end up with
something that looks a lot like a public
good like email. Like no one controls
email. There's no one who can take money
kind of extract money. And protocols
solve a political problem too. Kind of a
coordination problem. When you build a
network, you need all the kind of
participants of the network to to want
to join that network. And if they know
it's a public good that they can safely
build on top and one of their
competitors won't sort of secretly own
it and rug them, they're going to be
more likely to join that network. Then
there are corporate networks. Corporate
networks are, you know, Facebook,
Twitter, Visa. It's a network, but it's
very simple actually, you know,
architecturally just owned by a company.
They just own it. Now, the problem with
corporate networks is you're essentially
handing all this power over to that

Vis and Mastercard as an example, both

So, you know, there's a great book on

interesting to read about. So, now the
